column1: It's vital to start the day early for work on the farm.	Es esencial empezar el día temprano para el trabajo en la granja.	"
**Esencial**: Adjective, Feminine/Masculine (matches the gender of the noun it describes)
column2: meaning ""essential, vital."" Its origin is the Latin word ""essentialis.""
meaning ""to start"" or ""to begin"". Its basic root form is ""Empezar"". It comes from the Late Latin word ""in initiare,"" meaning to initiate.
meaning ""day"". It stems from the Latin word ""dies"".
meaning ""early"". It's derived from the Late Latin ""temporanus,"" meaning timely or early.
meaning ""work."" Its root is ""trabajar,"" which is considered of unknown origin although it's possibly from Latin translatus meaning adjusted.

meaning ""farm."" Originates from the word ""gran"", indicating large, and traditionally referred to a grand house or a villa. Over time it evolved to mean a farm — an extensive piece of land used for growing crops or raising animals."

column1: It's essential to calculate the costs of our planting and cultivation before the harvesting season begins.	Es esencial calcular los costos de nuestra siembra y cultivo antes de que comience la temporada de cosecha.	"

column3: root ""ser,"" from Latin ""esse.""
from Latin ""essentialis,"" theorized as based on essentia meaning ""being, essence"".
originating from Latin ""calculus,"" referring to ""pebble,"" but by metaphorical extension comes to mean ""reckoning
derived from Late Latin ""costus"".
from Latin ""de,"" indicating origin, separation, or content.
from Latin ""noster,"" which is based on ""nos"" meaning ""we"". Note that it is ""nuestra"" to match the feminine noun ""siembra.""
from Old Spanish ""siembro"" which was based on the Latin verb ""seminare,"" meaning ""to sow.""
from Latin ""et"". There are only rare cases where the etymology is shared like for common conjunctions and prepositions.
this is based around the Latin verb ""colere,"" with its forms ""cultus"" and ""cultivare,"" and meant a ""tilled"" and generally well-groomed terrain for agricultural purposes.

column2: meaning ""before"". Another instance of common phrases' etymology not generally briefed.

column3: from Latin ""quod"" or ""quia"", but this one appeared in Medieval Latin and modern forms, not classical Latin.
root ""comenzar,"" based on vulgar Latin ""cominiare,"" then the Latin verb meaning ""to initiate together.""
from late Latin term ""temporata"" referring to periodical weather or festivity.
from Latin ""de,"" indicating origin, derivation,

column1: or constitution as noun, and with many significations as prefix with verbs.

column3: from medieval 'cossecha,' possibly based on Latin ""collectionem"" returning to semantics of collection in general and a stored crop in particular."

column1: The agricultural machines make our work easier online.	Las maquinas agrícolas facilitan nuestro trabajo en línea.	"

means ""machines""

it means ""to facilitate or to make easier""

column2: can be either gender, but here it's masculine relating to ""trabajo"" (work)

means ""work""
column4: from the Latin ""trepalium,"" an ancient torture or punishment device consisting of three stakes (interesting because originally labour was seen as punishment or torture).

column3: Literally translates to ""in line,"" referencing the direct communication of computer networking, similar to telephone lines. Everyone forms part of the line that communicates directly with each other."

column1: The apple trees need to be pruned in the fall. 	Los manzanos necesitan ser podados en el otoño. 	"

column3: no significant etymology details.

Derived Spanish word from ""manzano"" which means ""apple tree."" The colonization of Hispanic America resulted in geographicisation of fruits leading the use of ""manzano"" for ""apple trees"" considering apples were often grown on trees.
root of verb ""necesitar,"" A derivative of the novel shortening of Latin compound phrase ""necessitatem habere"" where ""necessitätem"", denoted ""straitness, constriction, difficulty or trouble"".
This verb has Latin root ""esse,"" and stems from Indo-European root ""es-"" making it one of the comparatively unchanged Latin verbs in Spanish language.

column1: **Podados**: Verb, past participle in masculine plural
column3: root to the verb ""podar,"" which originally is derived from Latin ""putare portraying to cleanse.""

column1: **En el**: Preposition + Definite article, masculine singular
column3: no significant etymology details needed except for ""en,"" which originated from Latin ""in(dh)"" meaning ""in/to.""

column2: meaning ""fall"" or ""autumn"", Etymology traced around bronze era termed autumn from Greek Word ""opwto-res"" passing through many languages denotes very similar pronunciations back until Modern Spanish ""Otoño.""\"

column1: The harvest will start early due to the favorable weather.	La cosecha iniciará temprano debido al clima favorable.	"

column2: meaning ""the harvest,"" it refers to the process of collecting crops from the fields
column3: from Latin ""collegere"" meaning ""to gather.""
root Verb ""iniciar,"" from the Latin ""initiare"", meaning “to begin”.
from Latin ""temporaneum.""

column2: meaning ""due to"" is used to explain the causality
column3: combination of word ""debido"" which is a Past participle of word ""deber"" and ""a"".
combination of ""a"" (to) and ""el"" (the). Used before singular masculine nouns.
from Greek ""Klima"", originally meant “slope,"" metaphorically used as the slope or the inclination of the earth toward the sun from which weather arises.
a state that favors or promotes well-being

column1: During the harvest season, we wake up at dawn.	Durante la temporada de cosecha, nos despertamos al amanecer.	"

column3: from Latin ""durante,"" which is the present participle form of ""durāre"" meaning ""to last.''
the article ""la"" shows the gender (feminine) and number (singular) of the noun it precedes
derived from the verb ""temporar,"" meaning ""to season"" or ""temperance.""

column2: used to indicate possession or composition, among others
column3: in this case, it connects ""season"" with ""harvest""
of uncertain origin
from the root verb ""despertar"", a compound word from prefix ""des-"" (meaning opposition or negation) and ""pertar"" from Latin ""perterritare"" (to terrify excessively).
in this context ""al"" has the meaning of ""as soon as, at the time that"" ('al amanecer' = as soon as dawn breaks/dawns).
the infinitive here is treated like a masculine one in Spanish, ""el amanecer"" is a masculine noun meaning 'the dawning/the daybreak'
column4: from vulgar Latin ""manicēre,""which is formed by Latin a-, meaning intensive, and ""maneō,""  which means ""to remain."""
